awd_titl_txt: Conference: Conduct a Workshop to Develop a Proposal Addressing African Air Quality
awd_abstract_narration:
This workshop will identify key science questions that can help reveal novel atmospheric chemistry processes and data fusion techniques that could be applied to address poor air quality in African megacities. African megacities have a unique mix of pollutants, emission sources, and meteorology. The future economic development of these cities are distinct from other more well-studied regions in the US and Europe. This workshop will assess and report on observational and modeling requirements that can address the unique chemistry in the atmosphere of an African megacity. Understanding the evolving influence of African megacities on regional to global atmospheric chemistry is critical for both air pollution control at local scale levels as well as predicting their role in climate change. 

The workshop will be held on the campus of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and is planned as a 2.5-day meeting for September 13, 2023. A workshop web page will be used to announce workshop agenda, presentations, and final consensus reports. This effort will help develop a globally engaged scientific workforce that can focus on collaborative efforts to address the unique issues associated with air quality in African megacities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Outcomes Report for the General Public (POR)

  1. Describe the project outcomes or findings that address the intellectual merit and broader impacts of the work as defined in the NSF merit review criteria. This description should be a brief (generally, two to three paragraphs) summary of the project’s results that is written for the lay reader. PIs are strongly encouraged to avoid use of jargon, terms of art, or acronyms.

 

Intellectual Merit

The true complexities of problems found in African cities are not known due to lack of air quality monitoring capabilities. These capabilities would enable studies to characterize the unique chemistries in these environments and understand its impacts on the global atmosphere. The data sets that do exist are not always publicly available and/or strategically communicated, which limits public knowledge and effective policy making. Thus, the challenge is multifaceted.

 

There have been some regionally dependent findings, but an in-depth study of air pollution in Africa is severely lacking. In addition to long-term data collection, short-term intensive measurement campaigns with advanced instrumentation for detailed chemical analysis can provide deeper insight into the underlying sources and chemistry of air pollution. A detailed air quality study in a representative African city or several nearby cities may reveal novel atmospheric chemical processes that may not be common in highly sampled regions in the mid latitudes. This new information could have significant implications for improved chemical mechanisms for air quality models and could provide guidance for laboratory-scale process studies. The workshop identified and reported on the observational and modeling requirements for rigorous experimental design addressing the unique needs from an African megacity point of view. In the workshop there was discussions on what science goals can be accomplished from a short-term intensive measurement campaign and discuss requirements for a long-term data collection effort that may assist air quality regulators in Africa.

 

Broader Impacts

Urban air pollution is a pressing and multi-sectoral development challenge, representing a major health, economic, and social threat to cities of the global north and south. The discussions and deliberations at the workshop aided in the effort of developing a globally engaged workforce in the US and provide the opportunity for students to tackle problems of global magnitude as members of the world community. Participants acquired knowledge and research skills in international collaborations and the development of field campaigns through their participation in this workshop. These students interacted with peers, NCAR scientists, and international partners during the workshop, served as facilitators of the break-out sessions and note-takers. The workshop served as a launching point for future discussions, planning, and long-lasting relationships that create the conditions for joint global projects.

 

 

b. NSF will automatically include all publications associated with the award that are reported in annual and final project reports. Other products that have resulted from the award may also be listed. Examples of other products include collections, data sets, software, as well as educational materials.

 

  • List of African collaborators, organizations, and complementary measurements

 

  • Submitted a proposal: Phase 1 of the National Environment Research Council (NERC) large grant to tackle big environmental science questions. The proposal was successful, and team was invited to submit for Phase 2 due in November 2024.

 

  • Submitted a proposal: Belmont forum collaborative research actions-call for proposals:
  • Africa Regional Call.

 

  • Meeting notes and participant information from workshops.

 

  • Working groups in-country information on collaborators, organization, and capacity for Addis Ababa, Ethiopia and Nairobi Kenya.

 

  1. Information regarding anticipated publication of project results, as well as any other information that would be of interest to the public also may be included in this section.

 

Findings of from the workshop can be found in a peer reviewed publication: Bililign, Solomon, Steven S. Brown, Daniel M. Westervelt, Rajesh Kumar, Wenfu Tang, Frank Flocke, William Vizuete et al. "East African Megacity Air Quality: Rationale and Framework for a Measurement and Modeling Program." Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society 105, no. 8 (2024): E1584-E1602.
